metadata.title: 春秋二倍暦から見る日本書紀 - Observations on the Nihon Shoki from the Perspective of the Spring-Autumn Double-Year Calendar System(Japanese Version)
metadata.description:
本論は『日本書紀』の記録構造を春秋二倍暦という視点から再検討し、日本書紀と中国正史との編年整合を図ったものとなります。魏志倭人伝、倭の五王、欠史八代に至るまでの記録を暦法と、年代重複の観点から体系的に整理し、従来の年代解釈に新たな基礎的構造を提起しています。

 

変更履歴

This is the original Japanese-language version of the paper titled “Observations on the Nihon Shoki from the Perspective of the Spring-Autumn Double-Year Calendar System.”

The paper introduces a novel hypothesis that the Nihon Shoki recorded reign years using a Spring-Autumn double-year calendar system until the mid-5th century, and that this misunderstanding may have led to chronological inconsistencies in modern Japanese historiography.

By applying this structural reinterpretation, the paper successfully reconciles inconsistencies between the Nihon Shoki, Chinese dynastic records (including the Wei Zhi and Song Shu), and key archaeological findings such as the Inariyama Sword inscription.

The present version is written in Japanese and intended for readers who wish to engage with the argument in the original language of its development.

 

Revision History
・A supplementary note regarding Jingchu 3 was added to Section 2, and the formatting of paragraphs and tables throughout the text was revised to improve readability. ― August 2025

This interpretive model is proposed independently in this paper and does not follow existing academic chronologies.
It presents an original chronological interpretation based on the use of a biennial calendar prior to A.D. 470 and a reinterpretation of imperial reign years as indicators of longevity.

metadata.title: ImageJ Macros for measuring actin abundance on mitochondria
metadata.description:
These ImageJ macros are made for analysis of fluorescence micrographs, and allow the quantification of the intensity of one fluorophore that overlays another fluorophore.  We have used these to measure the quantification of actin intensity on mitochondria, but they can certainly be used for other combinations.

To get an explanation of how to use the files below, download a file and open it in ImageJ. Instructions for its use will be commnected at the top. Alternatively, click on the Repository URL which will take you to GitHub.  In GitHub, click on the file you wish to use, and an explanation of how to use it will appear, along with the code.

metadata.title: Eudamus hopfferi Plotz 1881
metadata.description:
Lectotype designation for Eudamus hopfferi Plötz, 1881

Eudamus hopfferi Plötz, 1881 was described from an unstated number of specimens that also included specimen(s) considered by Herrich-Schäffer (1869) to be a variation of Eudamus alector C. Felder & R. Felder, 1867 (type locality Colombia: Bogota) (now Telegonus alector alector, see below) with the white forewing band reduced to a smear, and the locality for these specimens was given as “Süd-America” (South America) (Plötz 1881). The type specimens of E. hopfferi labeled as such are unknown. Our search in the MFNB collection for Herrich-Schäffer specimens (Herrich-Schäffer Hesperiidae are mostly in MFNB) matching the description was unsuccessful. However, inspecting an unpublished manuscript by Plötz in ZSMC dated 1876, which is an earlier version of his published Hesperiidae keys, we found additional information about E. hopfferi (Fig. 60c): “Mus. Berol. 4969”, which is a reference to a specimen lot in MFNB with the number 4969. Plötz identified one (or more) specimen(s) in this lot as E. hopfferi, and therefore, such specimens (when agreeing with the original description) should be considered syntypes. While for many species described by Plötz, these specimen numbers were also listed in the published version of the keys, for E. hopfferi, the MFNB number was not given.

The catalog of historical MFNB collections handwritten by the Entomology curator Carl Heinrich Hopffer (died in 1876, before the description of E. hopfferi) contained an entry for the lot 4969 (Fig. 60d) showing that it was a single specimen collected by Deppe in Mexico and giving the name for it as “ Hesperia phanaeus N.” Ferdinand Deppe collected in Mexico in 1824–1829 (Stresemann 1954), and this specimen should have been collected then. The name “phanaeus ” was not published, and “N.” could be an abbreviation for the Latin “Nova ” [new] or “Nobis” [us], or German “Neue”, indicating that the name of the species was new (Zhang et al. 2023e). Hopffer labeled many Hesperiidae specimens in MFNB that he could not identify with such new names, but most of his names remained unpublished. Such species were subsequently described by other authors, who sometimes kept or modified Hopffer’s names, or proposed unrelated ones.

We found the specimen with the number 4969 in MFNB, shown in Fig. 60a with its labels. The specimen agrees well with the original description of E. hopfferi that we assembled from Plötz’s key and translate as: “Forewing without a central band on the upper surface. Hindwing not marked with white above. The underside of the forewing is broadly white towards the inner margin and tornus. Above, the body and wing bases are covered with shiny blue and green overscaling. On the underside, the costal margin of the forewing nearly to the apex is reddish-white gray, the white spot [by the tornus] extends very narrowly through the middle cell to the costal margin. Hindwing white at the base by costal margin, otherwise brown with 2 darker crossbands” (Plötz 1881). Moreover, the published illustration of Telegonus hopfferi in Draudt (1921–1924), reproduced here as Fig. 60b, may be a copy of Plötz’s unpublished (and lost) drawing t[afel]. 88 referenced in the original description and showing syntype (s) of E. hopfferi. Many Hesperiidae illustrations in Draudt (1921–1924), especially of obscure and recently described species, were not drawn from specimens, but from their illustrations in other sources, such as Plötz’s unpublished drawings. The illustration and the specimen are similar to each other, not only in the details of wing patterns, but also in the way the specimen was spread. This specimen No. 4969 may be the specimen drawn by Plötz, whose drawing was copied in Draudt (1921–1924).

As a result of these investigations, we conclude that the specimen No. 4969 is a syntype of E. hopfferi. Its appearance and associated data agree with the original description, unpublished manuscript by the original author, and published early illustrations of this taxon. Moreover, because Plötz did not wish to use the name “phanaeus,” likely coined by Hopffer for this new species, it seemed fitting to propose a name honoring Hopffer, who passed away in 1876. That is the year dated on Plötz’s manuscript with the name hopfferi, which was absent from his earlier manuscript (1870, also in ZSMC) that was a list of Hesperiidae species (including unpublished ones) known to Plötz at the time. Finally, the taxonomic identity of this syntype is in agreement with the current and prior use of this name in nearly all primary literature sources (Draudt 1922; Evans 1952; Mielke 2005) because Mexican populations, where this syntype is from, have been associated with this name.

To define the taxonomic identity of the name E. hopfferi objectively, N.V.G. hereby designates a syntype in the MFNB collection illustrated in Fig. 60a, a male with the following three labels (2nd handwritten and green, others printed and white): [4969], [Phanaeus | N. | Mexico Deppe], and [DNA sample ID: | NVG-22068G07 | c/o Nick V. Grishin] as the lectotype of Eudamus hopfferi Plötz, 1881. The lectotype is missing the tornus of the right hindwing. The COI barcode sequence of the lectotype, sample NVG-22068G07, GenBank PV550009, 658 base pairs, is: AACTTTATATTTTATTTTTGGAATTTGAGCAGGATTAATTGGAACTTCTTTAAGATTACTTATTCGAACTGAATTAGGAACTCCTGGATCTTTAATTGGAGATGATCAAATTTATAATACT ATTGTAACAGCTCACGCATTTATTATAATTTTTTTTATAGTTATACCTATTATAATTGGAGGATTTGGAAATTGATTAGTTCCATTAATAATAGGAGCCCCTGATATAGCTTTCCCCCGTA TAAATAATATAAGATTTTGACTTTTACCTCCATCATTAACTTTATTAATTTCAAGAAGAATTGTAGAAAATGGTGCTGGGACAGGATGAACAGTTTATCCCCCTCTTTCATCTAATATTGC CCATCAAGGAGCATCTGTTGACTTAGCAATTTTTTCTTTACATTTAGCTGGTATTTCTTCTATTCTTGGAGCTATTAATTTTATCACAACAATTATTAATATACGAATTAATAGTTTATCT TTTGATCAAATACCTTTATTTGTTTGAGCTGTAGGAATTACAGCATTATTATTATTACTTTCTTTACCAGTTTTAGCAGGAGCTATTACTATATTATTAACTGATCGAAATTTAAATACTT CATTTTTTGATCCAGCTGGAGGAGGAGATCCAATTTTATACCAACACTTATTT

As a result of the lectotype designation, the type locality of Eudamus hopfferi becomes Mexico, possibly in south-central or southern Mexico (states of Mexico, Puebla, Oaxaca, and around, but not more eastern territories, such as Veracruz), judging from Deppe’s travels (Stresemann 1954) and genomic sequence comparison that also confirms Thracides uridon Dyar, 1912 (type locality in Mexico: Guerrero, holotype sequenced as NVG-15101C12) as a junior subjective synonym of E. hopfferi (Fig. 61).

Finally, it remains unclear why Plötz gave the locality of E. hopfferi as South America even in the original manuscript that listed the Mexican specimen by its number 4969 (Fig. 60c). It could have been that the locality referred to Herrich-Schäffer specimen(s)—the locality is given in the same line with the reference to them (Plötz 1881), some other specimen(s) Plötz inspected, or it may be an error.
references: Plotz, C. 1881. Die Hesperiinen-Gattung Eudamus und ihre Arten. Stettiner entomologische Zeitung 42 (10 / 12): 500 - 504; 43 (1 / 3): 87-101.

Herrich-Schaffer, G. A. W. 1869. Prodromus systematis Lepidopterorum. Versuch einer systematischen Anordnung der Schmetterlinge. Correspondenz-Blatt des zoologisch-mineralogischen Vereines in Regensburg 23 (12): 184-204.
Stresemann, E. 1954. Ferdinand Deppe's travels in Mexico, 1824 - 1829. Condor 56 (2): 86-92.
Mielke, O. H. H. 2005. Catalogue of the American Hesperioidea: Hesperiidae (Lepidoptera). Sociedade Brasileira de Zoologia; Curitiba, Parana, Brazil. xxvi + 1536 pp.
Minh, B. Q., M. A. Nguyen, and A. von Haeseler. 2013. Ultrafast approximation for phylogenetic bootstrap. Molecular Biology and Evolution 30 (5): 1188-1195.

metadata.title: Reproduction Package for SPIN 2025 Article `TransVer: A Modular Program-Transformation Framework for Reduction to Reachability'
metadata.description:
TransVer: A Modular Program-Transformation Framework for Reduction to Reachability

Abstract

This is the Artifact for the paper “TransVer: A Modular Program-Transformation Framework for Reduction to Reachability” which has been accepted at SPIN 2025.

The SPIN article presents a program transformation framework with the goal of verifying different properties with of-the-shelf reachability analyzers. The transformations are in a framework based on instrumentation automata, inspired by the BLAST query language. In our initial study, we support three important concrete specifications for C programs: termination, no-overflow, and memory cleanup. This artifact can be used to reproduce the experiments presented in the paper. We demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our transformations by comparing verifiers that support the specifications natively with verifiers for reachability applied to the transformed programs. The results are very promising: Our transformations can extend existing verifiers to be effective on specifications that they do not support natively, and that the efficiency is often similar to verifiers that natively support the considered specifications.

The artifact consists of Makefile that can be used to setup all the tools and environment for the experiments. Moreover, it provides a simple interface for running all the scripts. Furthermore, it contains benchmarking definitions used by BenchExec to execute the experiments and processing scripts of the results that were used to generate the tables. The folder figures-generation/results-SPIN2025-proceedings-final contains all the data that we computed.

We assign 2 CPU cores, 15 GB of memory, and 900s of CPU time limit to each verification task. A reproduction of the full experiments would require more than 2 months of CPU time. Therefore, we prepared a subset of benchmarks for which the reproduction is faster. This reproduction package is intended to be run on the TACAS VM or on an Ubuntu 24.04 machine. Otherwise, the installation of the provided packages can break the operation system. If you wish to run it on a different OS, please install the requirements separately. We recommend viewing this README in its .html form as some links might not work otherwise.

Contents

  • README.md: this file containing documentation and useful tips
  • benchmark-defs/: directory with the requirement definitions for each tool required by BenchExec
  • benchmark-utils/: directory with scripts that check for the environment requirements for BenchExec
    • benchmark-utils/config.sh: file with parameters for BenchExec
    • benchmark-utils/check_configured.sh: file which checks that BenchExec is set up correctly
  • complete_logs/*: directory with logs from benchexec for all the tools and properties for smoke tests
  • figures-generation/: directory with scripts and definitions to produce the CSV files used to generate the plots in the paper
    • figures-generation/results-SPIN2025-proceedings-final: raw results of the experiments presented in the paper
    • figures-generation/results-SPIN2025-proceedings-final/final-table.html: all the results merged into an interactive table with CPU time, memory consumption and verdicts
  • scripts/ directory with scripts used to process the benchmarks
  • tasks/: directory with sets of tasks
    • tasks/{property}/all.xml: all tasks used to produce the results in the paper
    • tasks/{property}/subset.xml: subset of the tasks used in the paper
    • test/{property}/test.xml: one task used only for the smoke test of the artifact
  • transver/: directory of our tool TransVer that transforms the programs
  • Makefile: makefile with all the commands to set-up the environments, transform and verify all or just a subset of programs
  • License.txt: license information for the artifact
  • sv-benchmarks.zip: the SV-COMP25 benchmarks
  • packages: archive containing all the required packages
  • Tools:
    • CPAchecker: in archive cpachecker.zip
    • CPA-BAM-SMG: in archive cpa-bam-smg.zip
    • UAutomizer: in archive UAutomizer-linux.zip
    • UTaipan: in archive UTaipan-linux.zip
    • 2ls: in archive 2ls.zip
    • PredatorHP: in archive predatorhp.zip
    • Symbiotic: in archive symbiotic.zip
    • CPV: in archive cpv.zip
    • Theta: in archive Theta.zip
    • EmergenTheta: in archive EmergenTheta.zip
    • TransVer: TransVer at commit b8b380e9 in the folder transver using CPAchecker at commit 66247485

This README guides an user through the following steps:

  • A Modular Program-Transformation Framework for Reducing Specifications to Reachability
    • Abstract
    • Contents
    • TL;DR
    • Smoke Tests
    • Reusability
    • Set up the Environment
    • Experiments
    • Trouble Shooting

To reproduce the claims for our research questions, one needs to run the following:

  • RQ1: Verifiers can succesfully verify properties they do not natively support.
    • (a) Termination: One needs to transform the tasks with the termination transformation and run:
      • CPV, Theta, EmergenTheta on the transformed tasks
      • 2ls on the respective original tasks
    • (b) No-overflow: One needs to transform the tasks with the no-overflow transformation and run:
      • CPV, Theta, EmergenTheta on the transformed tasks
      • CPAchecker on the respective original tasks
  • RQ2 & RQ3: State-of-the-art reachability verifiers can be as effective and efficient as the native verifiers.
    • (a) Termination: One needs to transform the tasks with the termination transformation and run:
      • CPAchecker, UAutomizer on the transformed tasks
      • 2ls, UAutomizer on the respective original tasks
    • (b) No-overflow: One needs to transform the tasks with the no-overflow transformation and run:
      • CPAchecker, UAutomizer on the transformed tasks
      • CPAchecker, UAutomizer, UTaipan on the respective original tasks
    • (c) Memory-cleanup: One needs to transform the tasks with the memory-cleanup transformation and run:
      • CPAchecker, UAutomizer on the transformed tasks
      • Symbiotic, PredatorHP, CPA-BAM-SMG on the respective original tasks
  • RQ4: Reducing the verification task on C programs is not less efficient than doing the reduction on an intermediate abstraction.
    • (a) No-overflow: One needs to transform the tasks with the no-overflow transformation and run:
      • CPAchecker with predicate abstraction on the transformed tasks
      • CPAchecker on the respective original tasks
    • (b) Termination: One needs to transform the tasks with the termination transformation and run:
      • CPAchecker with termination-to-safety analysis on the transformed tasks
      • CPAchecker on the respective original tasks

TL;DR

  1. The full experiment runs require at least 15 GB of available memory and at least 2 available CPUs. If you run the artifact on TACAS VM, you can specify how much memory and how many CPUs you wish to allow to use:
vboxmanage import TACAS23-AEC.ova --vsys 0 --memory 16384 --cpus 2

If you do not have 16 GB of memory available, you can lower the limits for the runs to 7 GB with make set-lower-memory-limits. WARNING: After lowering the memory, our results will probably not be fully reproduced. (to switch back to 15GB, one can run make set-bigger-memory-limits)

  1. If inside the TACAS23 VM: If you use shared folder to load the artifact directory into the VM, please create a copy of the artifact on the VM and run all the commands from there cp -r <path_to_shared_folder>/<artifact_directory> /home/tacas23/. All the remaining steps should be then run from /home/tacas23/<artifact_directory>. The reason is that it might happen that the VM does not have permission to write or move files inside the shared folder.

  2. Setup variables in your shell environment(WARNING: this needs to be executed again after closing a terminal):

    • To execute on your local system or virtual machine use source benchmark-utils/config.sh.
    • If you have access to a BenchCloud instance use source benchmark-utils/config_vcloud.sh, adapting it correspondingly to your server.

  3. If inside the TACAS23 VM: Run make install-packages to install all needed packages, which are available with their corresponding license under packages.

    • WARNING: these packages are meant to be installed on the TACAS virtual machine or on a machine with Ubuntu 22.04 ! Installing them on a machine with different operating system might cause problems. Please refer to Trouble Shooting section for encountered errors.

  4. Run make setup-all to unzip all the needed tools and benchmarks. This step may take some time

  5. Select the tasks which you would like to use:

    • make setup-test: to setup a few tasks to test the functionality of the artifact
    • make setup-subset: to setup tasks to run a representative subset of tasks for the experiments in the paper
    • make setup-benchmark: to setup all tasks used in the experiments in the paper

  6. Transform the properties to reachability using make transform-programs. The transformed programs can be found in transformed_tasks_*/ and the original programs in original_tasks_*/.

  7. Execute the verification tasks on the original properties using make experiments-original-property

    • This command will run BenchExec to measure the resources consumed during the verification process. It is possible that after running it for the first time, one needs to create a partition in cgroups for BenchExec manually. If there is an error when running it for the first time, please run make add-cgroup-partition, for more details, we refer a reader to Trouble Shooting section of this file.
    • Executing the verification of all the tools for all the properties may take up to 1 hour. If you wish to run the tools for different properties, please have a look at Smoke Test.

  8. Execute the verification tasks where the original property has been encoded as a reachability property using make experiments-transformed

    • Executing the verification of all the tools for all the properties may take up to 1 hour. If you wish to run the tools for different properties, please have a look at Smoke Test.

Set up the Environment

To run the artifact BenchExec, Python >= 3.8, Java 17 and Podman are required. We provide an archive packages.zip with all required packages and the corresponding licenses. Follow the steps to install all of them either on your machine or on provided TACAS VM. If you run the artifact on TACAS VM, please allocate at least 15 GB of memory and 2 CPUs. This can be done with loading the VM with the following command:

vboxmanage import TACAS23-AEC.ova --vsys 0 --memory 16384 --cpus 2

NOTE: We assume that all of the commands are executed from inside the root directory of the artifact!

  1. If inside the TACAS23 VM: If you use shared folder to load the artifact directory into the VM, please create a copy of the artifact on the VM and run all the commands from there cp -r <path_to_shared_folder>/<artifact_directory> /home/tacas23/. All the remaining steps should be then run from /home/tacas23/<artifact_directory>. The reason is that it might happen that the VM does not have permission to write or move files inside the shared folder.
  2. run source benchmark-utils/config.sh (WARNING: needs to be repeated every time a new shell is opened)
  3. make setup-all to unzip all the archives with the tools and benchmarks
  4. If inside the TACAS23 VM: make install-packages to install all the required packages
  5. make switch-cgroup to switch to cgroups V1 which are needed to run benchexec
  6. If you do not have 15 GB of memory available, you can lower the limits for the runs to 7 GB with make set-lower-memory-limits. WARNING: After lowering the memory, our results will probably not be fully reproduced. (to switch back to 15GB, one can run make set-bigger-memory-limits)

Smoke Tests

Running our full experiments requires around 2 months of CPU time. We have selected few testing programs for quicker evaluation. The goal is to demonstrate the overall procedure that we did in order to run the experiments for our research questions. In this section, we explain how to run each transformation for handful of programs and how to verify them with each of the used tools. We assume that all the packages are installed, and that the tools and benchmarks are unzipped, following the Set up section.

Termination

We have chosen the following programs to demonstrate the termination transformation:

  • sv-benchmarks/c/termination-crafted/2Nested-1.c (expected verdict true)
  • sv-benchmarks/c/termination-crafted/Bangalore_v2.c (expected verdict false)
  1. run make setup-test-termination to prepare set files with these two programs
  2. run make transform-programs-termination to transform these two programs, their transformed versions are stored in transformed_tasks_t2r/ and their original versions are copied to original_tasks_t2r/
  3. The following commands will execute BenchExec to measure the performance of the verification tools, if you run it for the first time, it is possible, that it will throw an error. If that is the case, please run make add-cgroup-partition and this error should be fixed until switching off the machine. WARNING: This should be run after running at least once benchexec (i.e. some of the make experiment-* commands).
  4. run all the verifiers to test whether they work properly (some of them may take up to 15 minutes, as they are not able to solve the tasks in time), moreover some of them throw a known error on them which is expected:
  • tools verifying termination:
    • make experiment-uautomizer-verification-termination (Expected outcome: complete_logs/uautomizer_termination.txt)
    • make experiment-2ls-verification-termination (Expected outcome: complete_logs/2ls_termination.txt)
  • tools verifying reachability:
    • make experiment-uautomizer-verification-termination-transformed (Expected outcome: complete_logs/uautomizer_termination_transformed.txt)
    • make experiment-cpachecker-verification-termination-transformed (Expected outcome: complete_logs/cpachecker_termination_transformed.txt)
    • make experiment-cpv-verification-termination-transformed (Expected outcome: complete_logs/cpv_termination_transformed.txt)
    • make experiment-theta-verification-termination-transformed (Expected outcome: complete_logs/theta_termination_transformed.txt)
    • make experiment-emergentheta-verification-termination-transformed (Expected outcome: complete_logs/emergentheta_termination_transformed.txt)

Reusability

In this section, we show how to use our tool outside of the reproduction package. We show how to use TransVer for an arbitrary C program, that implies reusability of our tool. TransVer is available in a public git repository with instructions on how to use it. The general command line from transver repository is

transver.py --from-property <property> --to-property reachability --algorithm <algorithm> <program>

For example, we can use it on sv-benchmarks/c/termination-bwb/and-01.c like this

transver/transver.py --from-property termination --to-property reachability --algorithm InstrumentationOperator sv-benchmarks/c/termination-bwb/and-01.c

The transformed program is stored in output/transformed_input.c.

Reproduction of the Experiments

In this section, we explain how to run each transformation for selected set of programs and how to verify them with each of the used tools. We divide the evaluation by the research questions discussed in the paper and explain for each of them, how to reproduce the results. We assume that all the packages are installed, and that the tools and benchmarks are unzipped, following the Set up section.

Benchmark Selection

Depending on your available resources you can select different sets of benchmarks to execute the experiments. You have the following options:

  • A quick test with a single file, which can be useful to test that the artifact is behaving as intended. To select it use make setup-test-{property}. Executing this benchmark set with all the tools should take up to 2 hours.
  • We have selected a subset of the tasks used for the benchmarks in the paper. To select it use make setup-subset-{property}. Executing this benchmark set with all the tools can take around 2 days of CPU time. If one wants to try out the subset for at least one property and a tool to generate larger data, we recommend:
make setup-subset-termination
make transform-programs-termination
make experiment-uautomizer-verification-termination-transformed
  • The full benchmark set used in the experiments. To select it use make setup-benchmark-{property}. Executing this benchmark set will take around 60 days of CPU Time.

To run the transformation and verification on an arbitrary subset of programs, one can write a similar set file as for example sv-benchmarks/c/BitVectors-Termination.set. Afterwards, depending on the property, the tasks/<property>/subset.xml file needs to be updated with the set file. For example, to experiment with programs from sv-benchmarks/c/Loops.set with respect to the termination, one needs to change the line <includesfile>sv-benchmarks/c/BitVectors-Termination.set</includesfile> from tasks/termination/subset.xml to <includesfile>sv-benchmarks/c/Loops.set</includesfile> and then run the commands explained in the following section.

To do so, first select the benchmark set for the property (as described in the previous section) and then transform the programs for the property. An example for termination with subset of benchmarks:

make setup-subset-termination
make transform-programs-termination

Trouble Shooting

In this section, we discuss the known problems and possible ways how to solve them when running this artifact.

Cgroups for BenchExec

It is possible that when running BenchExec for the first time (especially on the TACAS VM), there is the following error:

2025-04-06 12:49:46,968 - WARNING - Ignoring specified resource requirements in local-execution mode, only resource limits are used.
2025-04-06 12:49:47,009 - INFO - Unable to find pqos_wrapper, please install it for cache allocation and monitoring if your CPU supports Intel RDT (cf. https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/software/pqos-wrapper).
2025-04-06 12:49:47,009 - WARNING - Cgroup subsystem cpuset is not available. Please make sure it is supported by your kernel and available.
2025-04-06 12:49:47,009 - ERROR - Cgroup subsystem cpuset is required for limiting the number of CPU cores/memory nodes.

The kernel has a bug where delegation of cpuset does not work if there are processes of other users in this user's cgroup.
This happens commonly if xdg-document-portal is running while such delegation is attempted for the first time.
For more information cf. https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/18293.
Linux 6.6 is expected to contain a fix for this bug.

As a quick workaround, execute this command, which forces the missing delegation as root user:
  echo +cpuset | sudo tee /sys/fs/cgroup/user.slice/user-1000.slice/user@1000.service/benchexec.slice/cgroup.subtree_control

To fix this issue, run the following command:

make add-cgroup-partition

WARNING: This command needs to be run after BenchExec was executed at least once. It needs to be run only once and then it works until the restart of the machine.

Expected Errors when Installing the Packages

The installation command make install-packages might throw some errors for already installed packages or for packages that are not needed in the reproduction of the experiments. However, these errors do not influence the reproduction of our experiments and can be ignored. Specifically for the TACAS VM, we expect the following errors:

Errors were encountered while processing:
 packages/gawk_1%3a5.1.0-1ubuntu0.1_amd64.deb
 packages/libgl1-mesa-dri_23.2.1-1ubuntu3.1~22.04.3_amd64.deb
 packages/libglib2.0-0_2.72.4-0ubuntu2.4_amd64.deb
 packages/libpam-modules_1.4.0-11ubuntu2.5_amd64.deb
 packages/libqt5gui5_5.15.3+dfsg-2ubuntu0.2_amd64.deb
 packages/python3_3.10.6-1~22.04.1_amd64.deb
make: *** [Makefile:98: install-packages] Error 1

Failed Instrumentation

When running make transform-programs-{property}, there might be a warning for some of the programs that looks like this:

The instrumentation of file {file} failed !

Please, ignore this warning. This just means that the program contains unsupported features for our transformation framework (like arrays for termination transformation) and therefore, TransVer does not transform the program.

CPU-throttling warnings

When you are running experiments (especially on a laptop), BenchExec might raise the following warning:

2024-XX-XX XX:XX:XX - WARNING - CPU throttled itself during benchmarking due to overheating. Benchmark results are unreliable!

This is normal on a laptop. Please ignore it.

metadata.title: Guide for Simulating Job Interviews through Role-Playing Activities - EMI Version
metadata.description:
In addition to the specific knowledge inherent to each academic discipline, advanced undergraduate courses, and particularly master’s programs, should aim to prepare students effectively for successful integration into the job market while fostering critical thinking skills. Specifically, in Chemistry studies, this preparation should encompass both technical and industry-specific content (such as legal regulations, commercial strategies, or safety protocols), as well as practical professional competencies (soft skills), including, for example, the ability to manage successfully a job interview.

The JOAQUIM project arises precisely with the main objective of integrating such practical skills into the curriculum for students in the final years of undergraduate and master’s studies in Chemistry. Within the framework of this project, and specifically in the subject Industry, Chemistry and Society in the Master’s Degree in Chemistry, we have designed a role-play activity that simulates a job recruitment process, including interviews.

This note presents a brief guide for implementing this activity, making it available to fellow educators who may wish to adapt or apply it in their own teaching contexts.

metadata.title: Practical Two-party Computational Differential Privacy with Active Security
metadata.description: In this work we revisit the problem of using general-purpose MPC schemes to emulate the trusted dataholder in differential privacy (DP), to achieve the same accuracy but without the need to trust one single dataholder. In particular, we consider the two-party model where two computational parties (or dataholders), each with their own dataset, wish to compute a canonical DP mechanism on their combined data and to do so with active security. We start by remarking that available definitions of computational DP (CDP) for protocols are somewhat ill-suited for such a use-case, due to them either poorly capturing some strong security guarantees commonly given by general-purpose MPC protocols, or having too strict requirements in the sense that they need significant adjustment in order to be satisfiable by using common DP and MPC techniques. With this in mind, we propose a new version of simulation-based CDP, called SIM*-CDP, and prove it to be stronger than the IND-CDP and SIM-CDP and incomparable to SIM+-CDP. We demonstrate the usability of the SIM*-CDP definition by showing how to satisfy it by the use of an available distributed protocol for sampling truncated geometric noise. Further, we use the protocol to compute two-party inner-products with CDP and active security, and with accuracy equal to that of the central model, being the first to do so. Finally, we provide an open-sourced implementation and benchmark its practical performance. Our implementation generates a truncated geometric sample in between about 0.035 and 3.5 seconds (amortized), depending on network and parameter settings, comparing favourably to existing implementations.
keywords: Differential privacy, Multiparty computation, UC-security, Noise sampling

metadata.title: Primer Corte: Entrevistas a montadores de cine y televisión
metadata.description:
La edición es tan esencial, tan decisiva, que cambiar al montador de una película es cambiar la película. La idea previa del guion puede ser fantástica, pero no deja de ser un deseo, una declaración de intenciones que termina chocando con las dificultades del rodaje. Por eso en montaje se reescribe lo rodado, marcando el tono de la interpretación o el ritmo de la narración.

Para descubrir los secretos de la sala de montaje hemos entrevistado a los profesionales actuales más importantes: Teresa Font (Dolor y Gloria, El día de la Bestia), Jaume Martí y Bernat Vilaplana (La sociedad de la nieve, Jurassic world), Nacho Ruiz Capillas (El 47, Maixabel), Iván Aledo (Mortadelo y Filemón, Los amantes del Círculo Polar), Ángel Hernández Zoido (Ocho apellidos vascos, La caja 507),Ana Pfaff (Alcarrás, Los días que vendrán), Fernando Franco (Robot dreams, Blancanieves), Alberto del Campo (As bestas, El reino), Vanessa Marimbert (El buen patrón), Luis de la Madrid (El espinazo del diablo), Victoria Lammers (La infiltrada)...

En total reúnen 16 premios Goya al Mejor Montaje y otras 47 nominaciones. Sin olvidar a los veteranos como Jaumandreu (Campanadas a medianoche), Del Rey (Tristana), Biurrun (Los santos inocentes) o Sinde (Volver a empezar).

Nos explican cómo se enfrentan al material, sus claves para un primer corte o cuando ya están afinando. Queríamos entender cómo es su vínculo con dirección y hasta qué punto tienen margen de maniobra para decidir.

Su experiencia es apabullante, tanto en largos como en las series más relevantes: Raúl Mora (La casa de papel, Reina roja), Alberto de Toro (Mira lo que has hecho), Irene Blecua (Élite, Cien años de soledad), Carolina Martínez Urbina (No me gusta conducir), Sergio Jiménez (Cardo).

Hablan de todo sin filtros: su software favorito para editar, sus dudas, miedos, aspiraciones, incluidos sus problemas y reivindicaciones laborales. Y por supuesto nos cuentan con todo detalle qué cualidades buscan en sus ayudantes y cómo hicieron ellos mismos cuando empezaron.

----

Esta es una versión corregida del libro Primer Corte: Entrevistas a montadores de cine y televisión, en la que se ha realizado una mínima corrección tipográfica.
